div1.p: THE DRUMMER; OR, THE HAUNTED HOUSE. A COMEDY. As it is Acted at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane, BY His MAJESTY's Servants.
LONDON: Printed for Jacob Tonson at Shakespear's-Head, over-against Katharine-Street in the Strand. MDCCXV

div1.head: THE PREFACE.
div1.p: HAving recommended this Play to the Town, and delivered the Copy of it to the Bookseller, I think my self oblig'd to give some Account of it.

It had been some Years in the Hands of the Author, and falling under my Perusal, I thought so well of it that I persuaded him to make a few Additions and Alterations to it, and let it appear upon the Stage. I own I was very highly pleased with it, and lik'd it the better, for the want of those studyed Similes and Repartees, which we, who have writ before him, have thrown into our Plays, to indulge and gain upon a false Taste that has prevailed for many Years in the British Theatre. I believe the Author would have fallen into this Way a little more than he has, had he, before the writing of it, been often present at Theatrical Representations, and observ'd the Effect that such Ornaments generally have upon the Town. I was confirmed in my Thoughts of the Play, by the Opinion of better Judges to whom it was Communicated, who observed that the Scenes were written very much after Moliere's Manner, and that an easie and natural Vein of Humour ran through the whole.

I do not question but the Reader will discover this, and see many Beauties that escape the Audience; the Touches
being too delicate for every Taste in a Popular Assembly. My Brother-Sharers were of Opinion, at the first reading of it, that it was like a Picture in which the Strokes were not strong enough to appear with Advantage at a Distance. As it is not in the common way of Writing, the Approbation was at first Doubtful, but has risen every time it has been Acted, and has given an Opportunity in several of its Parts for as just and good Action as I ever saw on the Stage.

The Reader will consider that I speak here as the Patentee, for which Reason I forbear being more particular in the Character of this Play, least I should appear like one, who cries up the Wares of his own Shop to draw in Customers.

lg.l: IN this Grave Age, when Comedies are few,
We crave your Patronage for one that's New;
Tho' 'twere poor Stuff, yet bid the Author fair,
And let the Scarceness recommend the Ware.
Long have your Ears been fill'd with Tragick Parts,
Blood and Blank-Verse have harden'd all your Hearts;
If e'er you smile, 'tis at some Party-Stroaks,
Round-heads and Wooden-shooes are standing Jokes;
The same Conceit gives Claps and Hisses Birth,
You're grown such Politicians in your Mirth!
For once we try (tho' 'tis, I own, unsafe)
To please you All, and make both Parties laugh.
Our Author, anxious for his Fame to Night,
And bashful in his First Attempt to write,
Lies cautiously obscure and unreveal'd,
Like Ancient Actors in a Masque conceal'd.
Censure, when no Man knows who writes the Play,
Were much good Malice merely thrown away.
The mighty Criticks will not blast, for Shame,
A raw young Thing, who dares not tell his Name:
Good-natur'd Judges will th' unknown defend,
And fear to blame, least they shou'd hurt a Friend:
Each Wit may praise it, for his own dear Sake,
And hint He writ it, if the Thing shou'd take.
But, if you're rough, and use him like a Dog,
Depend upon it—He'll remain Incog.
If you shou'd hiss, he swears He'll hiss as high,
And, like a Culprit, joyn the Hue-and-Cry.
If Cruel Men are still averse to spare
These Scenes, they fly for Refuge to the Fair.
Tho' with a Ghost our Comedy be heighten'd,
Ladies upon my Word you shan't be frighten'd;
O, 'tis a Ghost that scorns to be uncivil,
A well-spread, lusty, Jointure-hunting Devil;
An Am'rous Ghost, that's faithful, fond and true,
Made up of Flesh and Blood—as much as you.
Then every Evening come in Flocks, undaunted;
We never think this House is too much Haunted.

div1.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div1.stage: Enter the Butler, Coachman, and Gardiner.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: THERE came another Coach to Town last Night, that brought a Gentleman to enquire about this strange Noise, we hear in the House. This Spirit will bring a power of Custom to the George—If so be he continues his Pranks, I design to sell a Pot of Ale, and set up the Sign of the Drum.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: I'll give Madam warning, that's flat—I've always liv'd in Sober Families. I'll not disparage my self to be a Servant in a House that is haunted.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I'll e'en marry Nell, and rent a bit of Ground of my own, if both of you leave Madam; not but that Madam's a very good Woman—if Mrs. Abigal did not spoil her—come, here's her Health.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: It's a very hard thing to be a Butler in a House, that is disturb'd. He made such a Racket in the Cellar last Night, that I'm afraid he'll sower all the Beer in my Barrels.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Why then, John, we ought to take it off as fast as we can. Here's to you—He rattled so loud under the Tiles last Night, that I verily thought the House wou'd have fallen over our Heads. I durst not go up into the Cock-Loft this Morning, if I had not got one of the Maids to go along with me.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I thought I heard him in one of my Bed-Posts—I marvel, John, how he gets into the House when all the Gates are shut.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why look ye Peter, your Spirit will creep you into an Augre-Hole:—he'll whisk ye through a Key-Hole, without so much as justling against one of the Wards.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Poor Madam is mainly frighted that's certain, and verily believes 'tis my Master that was kill'd in the last Campaign.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Out of all manner of Question, Robin, 'tis Sir George. Mrs. Abigal is of Opinion it can be none but his Honour; he always lov'd the Wars, and you know was mightily pleas'd from a Child with the Musick of a Drum.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I wonder his Body was never found after the Battle.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Found! Why, ye Fool, is not his Body here about the House? Dost thou think he can beat his Drum without Hands and Arms?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: 'Tis Master as sure as I stand here alive, and I verily believe I saw him last Night in the Town-Close.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Ay! how did he appear?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Like a White-Horse.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Pho, Robin, I tell ye he has never appear'd yet but in the Shape of the Sound of a Drum,

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: This makes one almost afraid of one's own Shadow. As I was walking from the Stable t'other Night without my Lanthorn, I fell a-cross a Beam, that lay in my way, and Faith my Heart was in my Mouth—I thought I had stumbled over a Spirit.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Thou might'st as well have stumbled over a Straw; why, a Spirit is such a little little Thing, that I have heard a Man, who was a great Scholar, say, that he'll dance ye a Lancashire Horn-Pipe upon the point of a Needle—As I sat in the Pantry last Night counting my Spoons, the Candle methought burnt blue, and the spay'd Bitch look'd as if she saw something.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Ay poor Cur, she's almost frighten'd out of her Wits.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Ay I warrant ye, she hears him many a time and often when we don't.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: My Lady must have him Laid, that's certain, whatever it cost her.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I fancy, when one goes to Market, one might hear of some body that can make a Spell.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Why may not the Parson of our Parish lay him?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: No, no, no, our Parson cannot lay him.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Why not he as well as another Man?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why, ye Fool, he is not qualified—He has not taken the Oaths.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Why, d'ye think John, that the Spirit wou'd take the Law of him?—faith, I cou'd tell you one way to drive him off.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I'll tell you immediately [drinks]—I fancy Mrs. Abigal might Scold him out of the House.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Ay, she has a Tongue that would drown his Drum, if any thing cou'd.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Pugh, this is all froth! you understand nothing of the Matter—the next time it makes a Noise, I tell you what ought to be done,—I wou'd have the Steward speak Latin to it.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Ay that wou'd do, if the Steward had but Courage.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: There you have it—He's a fearful Man. If I had as much Learning as he, and I met the Ghost, I'd tell him his own! but alack what can one of us poor Men do with a Spirit, that can neither Write nor Read?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Thou art always cracking and boasting, Peter, thou dost not know what Mischief it might do thee, if such a silly Dog as thee should offer to speak to it. For ought I know, he might flea thee alive, and make Parchment of thy Skin to cover his Drum with.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: A Fidlestick! tell not me—I fear nothing; not I! I never did harm in my Life, I never committed Murder.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I verily believe thee, keep thy Temper, Peter; after Supper we'll drink each of us a double Mug, and then let come what will.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Why that's well said John, an honest Man that is not quite sober, has nothing to fear—Here's to ye—why how if he shou'd come this Minute, here wou'd I stand. Ha! what Noise is that?

sp.speaker: But. & Coach.
sp.p: Ha! where?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: The Devil! the Devil! Oh no, 'tis Mrs. Abigal.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Ay faith! 'tis she; 'tis Mrs. Abigal! a good Mistake! 'tis Mrs. Abigal.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Here are your drunken Sots for you! Is this a time to be guzling, when Gentry are come to the House! why don't You lay your Cloth? How come You out of the Stables? Why are not You at work in your Garden?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Why, yonder's the fine Londoner and Madam fetching a walk together, and me-thought they look'd as if they should say they had rather have my Room than my Company.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And so forsooth being all three met-together, we are doing our Endeavours to drink this same Drummer out of our Heads.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: For you must know, Mrs. Abigal, we are all of Opinion that one can't be a Match for him, unless one be as Drunk as a Drum.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: I am resolved to give Madam Warning to hire herself another Coachman; for I came to serve my Master, d'ye see, while he was alive, but do suppose that he has no further occasion for a Coach, now he Walks.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Truly, Mrs. Abigal, I must needs say, that this same Spirit is a very odd sort of a Body, after all, to fright Madam and his old Servants at this rate.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: And truly, Mrs. Abigal, I must needs say, I serv'd my my Master contentedly, while he was living; but I will serve no Man living (that is, no Man that is not living) without double Wages.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis such Cowards as you that go about with Idle Stories, to disgrace the House, and bring so many Strangers about it; you first frighten your selves, and then your Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Frighten'd! I scorn your Words. Frighten'd quoth-a!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: What you Sot! are you grown Pot-valiant?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Frighten'd with a Drum! that's a good one! it will do us no harm, I'll answer for it. It will bring no Blood-shed along with it, take my Word. It sounds as like a Train-Band Drum as ever I heard in my Life.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Prithee, Peter, don't be so presumptuous.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Well, these drunken Rogues take it as I cou'd wish. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I scorn to be frightned, now I am in for't; if old Dub-a-dub shou'd come into the Room, I wou'd take him—

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy Tongue.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I would take him—
sp.stage: [The Drum beats, the Gard. endeavours to get off, and falls.

sp.speaker: But. & Coach.
sp.p: Speak to it, Mrs. Abigal.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Spare my Life, and take all I have.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Make off, make off, good Butler, and let us go hide our selves in the Cellar.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: So, now the Coast is clear, I may venture to call out my Drummer.—But first let me shut the Door, lest we be surpriz'd. Mr. Fantome, Mr. Fantome! [He beats.] Nay, nay, pray come out, the Enemy's fled—I must speak with you immediately—don't stay to beat a Parley.
sp.stage: [The back Scene opens and discovers Fantome with a Drum.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Nabby, I have overheard all that has been said, and find thou hast manag'd this thing so well, that I cou'd take thee in my Arms, and kiss thee—if my Drum did not stand in my way.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Well, O' my Conscience, you are the merriest Ghost! and the very Picture of Sir George Truman.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: There you flatter me, Mrs. Abigal; Sir George had that freshness in his Looks, that we Men of the Town cannot come up to.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh! Death may have alter'd you, you know—besides, you must consider, you lost a great deal of Blood in the Battle.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Ay, that's right; let me look never so pale, this Cut cross my Forehead will keep me in Countenance.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: 'Tis just such a one as my Master receiv'd from a cursed French Trooper, as my Lady's Letter inform'd her.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: It happens luckily that this Suit of Cloaths of Sir George's fits me so well,—I think I can't fail hitting the Air of a Man with whom I was so long acquainted.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: You are the very Man—I vow I almost start when I look upon you.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: But what good will this do me, if I must remain invisible?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Pray what good did your being visible do you? the fair Mr. Fantome thought no Woman cou'd withstand him—But when you were seen by my Lady in your proper Person, after she had taken a full survey of you, and heard all the pretty things you cou'd say, she very civilly dismiss'd you for the sake of this empty, noisy Creature Tinsel. She fancies you have been gone from hence this Fortnight.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Why really I love thy Lady so well, that tho' I had no hopes of gaining her for my self, I cou'd not bear to see her given to another, especially to such a Wretch as Tinsel.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Well, tell me truly Mr. Fantome, have not you a great Opinion of my Fidelity to my dear Lady, that I wou'd not suffer her to be deluded in this manner, for less than a Thousand Pound?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Thou art always reminding me of my Promise—thou shalt have it, if thou canst bring our Project to bear; do'st not know that Stories of Ghosts and Apparitions generally end in a Pot of Money?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Why, truly now Mr. Fantome, I shou'd think my self a very bad Woman, if I had done what I do, for a Farthing less.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Dear Abigal, how I admire thy Virtue!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: No, no, Mr. Fantome, I defy the worst of my Enemies to say I love Mischief for Mischief sake.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: But is thy Lady perswaded that I am the Ghost of her deceased Husband?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I endeavour to make her believe so, and tell her every time your Drum rattles, that her Husband is chiding her for entertaining this new Lover:

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Prithee make use of all thy Art, for I am tir'd to Death with strowling round this wide Old House, like a Rat behind a Wainscot.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Did not I tell you, 'twas the purest place in the World for you to play your Tricks in; there's none of the Family that knows every Hole and Corner in it, besides my self.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Ah Mrs. Abigal! You have had your Intrigues.—

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: For you must know when I was a romping young Girl I was a mighty lover of Hide and Seek.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: I believe, by this Time, I am as well acquainted with the House as your self.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p:
You are very much mistaken, Mr. Fantome; but no matter for that; here is to be your Station to Night. This is the Place unknown to any one living besides my self, since the Death of the Joyner; who, you must understand, being a Lover of mine, contriv'd the Wainscot to move to and fro, in the manner that you find it. I design'd it for a Wardrobe for my Lady's cast
Cloaths. Oh! the Stomachers, Stays, Pettycoats, Commodes, lac'd Shooes, and good things that I have had in it!—pray take care you don't break the Cherry-Brandy Bottle, that stands up in the Corner.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Well Mrs. Abigal, I hire your Closet of you, but for this one Night—a thousand Pound you know is a very good Rent.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Well, get you gone; you have such a way with you there's no denying you any thing!

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: I'm a thinking how Tinsel will stare, when he sees me come out of the Wall: for I am resolved to make my Appearance to Night.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Get you in, get you in, my Lady's at the Door.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Pray take care she does not keep me up so late, as she did last Night; or depend upon it I'll beat the Tattoo.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I'm undone, I'm undone— [As he is going in] Mr. Fantome, Mr. Fantome, you have put the thousand Pound Bond into my Brother's Hands.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Thou shalt have it, I tell thee, thou shalt have it.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: No more Words—Vanish, Vanish.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: [opening the Door] Oh, dear Madam, was it you that made such a knocking? my Heart does so beat—I vow you have frighted me to Death—I thought verily it had been the Drummer.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have been showing the Garden to Mr. Tinsel; he's most insufferably witty upon us about this Story of the Drum.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, he's a very loose Man! I'm afraid 'tis he that hinders my poor Master from resting in his Grave.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well! an Infidel is such a Novelty in the Country, that I am resolv'd to divert my self a Day or two at least with the Oddness of his Conversation.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ah, Madam! the Drum begun to beat in the House as soon as ever this Creature was admitted to visit you. All the while Mr. Fantome made his Addresses to you, there was not a Mouse stirring in the Family more than us'd to be—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This Baggage has some Design upon me, more than I can yet discover. [aside]—Mr. Fantome was always thy Favourite.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p:
Ay, and shou'd have been yours too, by my Consent! Mr.
Fantome was not such a slight fantastick thing as this is.—Mr. Fantome was the best-built Man one shou'd see in a Summer's Day! Mr. Fantome was a Man of Honour, and lov'd you! Poor Soul! how has he sigh'd when he has talk'd to me of my hardhearted Lady—Well! I had as lief as a thousand Pound, you wou'd marry Mr. Fantome!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To tell thee-truly, I lov'd him well enough till I found he lov'd me so much. But Mr. Tinsel makes his Court to me with so much Neglect and Indifference, and with such an agreeable Sauciness—Not that I say I'll marry him.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Marry him, quoth-a! no, if you should, you'll be awaken'd sooner than married Couples generally are—You'll quickly have a Drum at your Window.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll hide my Contempt of Tinsel for once, if it be but to see what this Wench drives at. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Why, suppose your Husband, after this fair Warning he has given you, shou'd sound you an Alarm at Midnight; then open your Curtains with a Face as pale as my Apron, and cry out with a hollow Voice, What dost thou do in Bed with this Spindle-shank'd Fellow?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why wilt thou needs have it to be my Husband? he never had any reason to be offended at me. I always lov'd him while he was living, and shou'd prefer him to any Man, were he so still. Mr. Tinsel is indeed very idle in his Talk, but I fancy, Abigal, a discreet Woman might reform him.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: That's a likely matter indeed; did you ever hear of a Woman who had Power over a Man, when she was his Wife, that had none while she was his Mistress! Oh! there's nothing in the World improves a Man in his Complaisance like Marriage!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He is indeed, at present, too familiar in his Conversation.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Familiar! Madam, in Troth he's down-right rude.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But that you know, Abigal, shows he has no Dissimulation in him—Then he is apt to jest a little too much upon grave Subjects.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Grave Subjects! he jests upon the Church.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But that you know, Abigal, may be only to show his Wit—Then it must be own'd, he is extreamly Talkative.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Talkative d'ye call it! he's down-right Impertinent.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But that you know, Abigal, is a Sign he has been us'd to good Company—Then indeed he is very positive.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Positive! Why he contradicts you in every thing you say.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But then you know, Abigal, he has been educated at the Inns of Court.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: A blessed Education indeed! it has made him forget his Catechism!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You talk as if you hated him.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: You talk as if you lov'd him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue! here he comes.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: My dear Widow!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: My dear Widow! marry come up! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Let him alone, Abigal; so long as he does not call me My dear Wife, there's no Harm done.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I have been most ridiculously diverted since I left you—Your Servants have made a Convert of my Booby. His Head is so filled with this foolish Story of a Drummer, that I expect the Rogue will be afraid hereafter to go upon a Message by Moon-light.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Tinsel, what a Loss of Billet-doux would that be to many a fine Lady!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Then you still believe this to be a foolish Story? I thought my Lady had told you, that she had heard it her self.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Why, you would not perswade us out of our Senses?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: There's Manners for you, Madam. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Admirably rally'd! that Laugh is unanswerable! Now I'll be hang'd if you could forbear being witty upon me, if I should tell you I heard it no longer ago than last Night.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Fancy!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But what if I should tell you my Maid was with me!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Vapours! Vapours! Pray, my dear Widow, will you answer me one Question?—Had you ever this Noise of a Drum in your Head, all the while your Husband was living?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And pray, Mr. Tinsel, will you let me ask you another Question? Do you think we can Hear in the Country, as well as you do in Town?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Believe me, Madam, I could prescribe you a Cure for these Imaginations.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Don't tell my Lady of Imaginations, Sir, I have heard it my self.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Hark thee, Child—art thou not an old Maid?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Sir, if I am, it is my own Fault.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Whims! Freaks! Megrims! indeed Mrs. Abigal.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Marry, Sir, by your Talk one would believe you thought every thing that was good is a Megrim.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why truly I don't very well understand what you meant by your Doctrine to me in the Garden just now, that every thing we saw was made by Chance.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: A very pretty Subject indeed for a Lover to divert his Mistress with.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But I suppose that was only a Taste of the Conversation you would entertain me with after Marriage.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Oh, I shall then have time to read you such Lectures of Motions, Atoms, and Nature—that you shall learn to think as Freely as the best of us, and be convinced in less than a Month, that all about us is Chance-work.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You are a very complaisant Person indeed; and so you would make your Court to me, by perswading me that I was made by Chance!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! well said, my Dear! why, faith, thou wert a very lucky Hit, that's certain!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Tinsel, where did you learn this odd way of talking?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Ah, Widow, 'tis your Country Innocence makes you think it an odd way of talking.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Tho' you give no Credit to Stories of Apparitions, I hope you believe there are such things as Spirits!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Simplicity!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I fancy you don't believe Women have Souls, d'ye Sir?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Foolish enough!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I vow, Mr. Tinsel, I'm afraid malicious People will say I'm in Love with an Atheist.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Oh, my Dear, that's an old-fashion'd Word—I'm a Free-thinker, Child.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I am sure you are a Free-speaker!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Really, Mr. Tinsel, considering that you are so fine a Gentleman, I'm amaz'd where you got all this Learning! I wonder it has not spoil'd your Breeding.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: To tell you the Truth, I have not time to look into these dry Matters my self, but I am convinc'd by four or five learned Men, whom I sometimes over-hear at a Coffee-house I frequent, that our Fore-fathers were a Pack of Asses, that the World has been in an Error for some Thousands of Years, and that all the People upon Earth, excepting those two or three worthy Gentlemen, are impos'd upon, cheated, bubbled, abus'd, bamboozl'd—

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Madam, how can you hear such a Profligate? he talks like the London Prodigal.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why really, I'm a thinking, if there be no such things as Spirits, a Woman has no Occasion for marrying—She need not be afraid to lye by her self.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Ah! my Dear! are Husbands good for nothing but to frighten away Spirits? Dost thou think I could not instruct thee in several other Comforts of Matrimony?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah! but you are a Man of so much Knowledge, that you would always be laughing at my Ignorance—You learned Men are so apt to despise one!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: No, Child! I'd teach thee my Principles, thou should'st be as wise as I am—in a Week's time.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you think your Principles would make a Woman the better Wife?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Prithee, Widow, don't be queer.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I love a gay Temper, but I would not have you rally things that are serious.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Well enough faith! where's the Jest of rallying any thing else!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, did you ever hear Mr. Fantome talk at this Rate? [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: But where's this Ghost! this Son of a Whore of a Drummer? I'd fain hear him methinks.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, don't suffer him to give the Ghost such ill Language, especially when you have Reason to believe it is my Master.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p:
That's well enough faith; Nab; dost thou think thy Master is so unreasonable, as to continue his Claim to his Relict
after his Bones are laid? Pray, Widow, remember the Words of your Contract, you have fulfill'd them to a Tittle—Did not you marry Sir George to the Tune of 'till Death us do part?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I must not hear Sir George's Memory treated in so slight a Manner—This Fellow must have been at some Pains make himself such a finish'd Coxcomb. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Give me but Possession of your Person, and I'll whirle you up to Town for a Winter, and cure you at once. Oh! I have known many a Country Lady come to London with frightful Stories of the Hall-House being haunted, of Fairies, Spirits, and Witches; that by the time she had seen a Comedy, play'd at an Assembly, and ambled in a Ball or two, has been so little afraid of Bugbears, that she has ventur'd home in a Chair at all Hours of the Night.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Hum—Sauce-box. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: 'Tis the Solitude of the Country that creates these Whimsies; there was never such a thing as a Ghost heard of at London, except in the Play-house—Oh we'd pass all our time in London. 'Tis the Scene of Pleasure and Diversions, where there's something to amuse you every Hour of the Day. Life's not Life in the Country.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well then, you have an Opportunity of showing the Sincerity of that Love to me which you profess. You may give a Proof that you have an Affection to my Person, not my Jointure.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Your Jointure! How can you think me such a Dog! But, Child, won't your Jointure be the same thing in London as in the Country?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, you're deceiv'd! You must know it is settled on me by Marriage-Articles, on Condition that I live in this old Mansion-House, and keep it up in Repair.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: That's well put, Madam.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Why faith I have been looking upon this House, and think it is the prettiest Habitation I ever saw in my Life.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay, but then this cruel Drum!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Something so venerable in it!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay, but the Drum!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: For my part, I like this Gothick Way of Building better than any of your new Orders—it wou'd be a thousand pities it shou'd fall to Ruin.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay, but the Drum!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: How pleasantly we two could pass our Time in this delicious Situation. Our Lives wou'd be a continued Dream of Happiness. Come, faith, Widow, let's go upon the Leads, and take a View of the Country.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay, but the Drum! the Drum!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: My Dear, take my Word for't 'tis all Fancy: Besides, shou'd he drum in thy very Bed-Chamber, I shou'd only hug thee the closer.
sp.l: Clasp'd in the Folds of Love, I'd meet my Doom,
And act my Joys, tho' Thunder shook the Room.

div1.head: ACT II. SCENE I.
div1.stage: SCENE opens, and discovers Vellum in his Office, and a Letter in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: THIS Letter astonisheth; may I believe my own Eyes—or rather my Spectacles—

To Humphrey Vellum Esq Steward to the Lady Truman.
Vellum, I Doubt not but you will be glad to hear your Master is alive, and designs to be with you in half an Hour. The Report of my being slain in the Netherlands, has, I find, produced some Disorders in my Family. I am now at the George-Inn: If an old Man with a grey Beard, in a black Cloak, enquires after you, give him Admittance. He passes for a Conjurer, but is really
Your Faithful Friend, G. Truman.
P.S. Let this be a Secret, and you shall find your Account in it.
This amazeth me! and yet the Reasons why I should believe he is still living are manifold—First, Because this has often been the Case of other Military Adventurers.
Secondly, Because the News of his Death was first publish'd in Dier's Letter.
Thirdly, Because this Letter can be written by none but himself—I know his Hand, and manner of Spelling.
Fourthly,—

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir, here's a strange old Gentleman that asks for you; he says he's a Conjurer, but he looks very suspicious; I wish he ben't a Jesuit.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Admit him immediately.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I wish he ben't a Jesuit; but he says he's nothing but a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: He says right—He is no more than a Conjurer. Bring him in and withdraw. [Exit Butler.
And Fourthly, As I was saying, Because—

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir, here is the Conjurer—What a devilish long Beard he has! I warrant it has been growing these hundred Years. [Aside. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Dear Vellum, you have receiv'd my Letter: But before we proceed lock the Door.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It is his Voice.

sp.speaker: Sir. G.
sp.p: In the next place help me off with this cumbersome Cloak.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It is his Shape.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: So, now lay my Beard upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: [After having look'd on Sir George thro'd his Spectacles] It is his Face, every Lineament!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Well now, I have put off the Conjurer and the old Man, I can talk to thee more at my Ease.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Believe me, my good Master, I am as much rejoiced to see you alive, as I was upon the Day you were born. Your Name was, in all the News-Papers, in the List of those that were slain.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: We have not Time to be particular. I shall only tell thee in general, that I was taken Prisoner in the Battle, and was under close Confinement for several Months. Upon my Release, I was resolv'd to surprize my Wife with the News of my being alive. I know, Vellum, you are a Person of so much Penetration, that I need not use any further Arguments to convince you that I am so:

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I am—and moreover, I question not but your good Lady will likewise be convinced of it. Her Ho—nour is a discerning Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I'm only afraid she shou'd be convinc'd of it to her Sorrow. Is not she pleas'd with her imaginary Widowhood? Tell me truly, was she afflicted at the Report of my Death?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Sorely.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: How long did her Grief last?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Longer than I have known any Widow's—at least three Days.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Three Days, sayst thou? Three whole Days? I'm afraid thou flatterest me!—O Woman! Woman!

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Grief is twofold.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: This Blockhead is as methodical as ever—but I know he's honest. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: There is a real Grief, and there is a methodical Grief; she was drown'd in Tears 'till such time as the Taylor had made her Widow's Weeds—Indeed they became her.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Became her! And was that her Comfort? Truly a most seasonable Consolation!

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: But I must needs say she paid a due Regard to your Memory, and could not forbear weeping when she saw Company.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: That was kind indeed! I find she griev'd with a great deal of Good-Breeding. But how comes this Gang of Lovers about her?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Her Jointure is considerable.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: How this Fool torments me! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Her Person is amiable—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Death! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: But her Character is unblemish'd. She has been as virtuous in your Absence as a Penelope—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: And has had as many Suitors.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Several have made their Overtures.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Several!

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: But she has rejected all.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: There thou reviv'st me—But what means this Tinsel? Are his Visits acceptable?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: He is young.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Does she listen to him?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: He is gay.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Sure she could never entertain a Thought of marrying such a Coxcomb!

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: He is not ill made.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Are the Vows and Protestations that past between us come to this! I can't bear the Thought of it! Is Tinsel the Man design'd for my worthy Successor?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: You do not consider that you have been dead these fourteen Months—

sp.speaker: Sir. G.
sp.p: Was there ever such a Dog? [Aside.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: And I have often heard her say, that she must never expect to find a second Sir G. Truman—meaning your Ho—nour.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I think she lov'd me; but I must search into this Story of the Drummer before I discover my self to her. I have put on this Habit of a Conjurer, in order to introduce my self. It must be your Business to recommend me as a most profound Person, that by my great Knowledge in the curious Arts can silence the Drummer, and dispossess the House.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I am going to lay my Accounts before my Lady, and I will endeavour to prevail upon her Ho—nour to admit the Tryal of your Art.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I have scarce heard of any of these Stories that did not arise from a Love Intrigue—Amours raise as many Ghosts as Murders.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Mrs. Abigal endeavours to perswade us, that 'tis your Ho—nour who troubles the House.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: That convinces me 'tis a Cheat; for I think, Vellum, I may be pretty well assur'd it is not me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I am apt to think so truly. Ha—ha—ha!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Abigal had always an Ascendant over her Lady, and if there is a Trick in this Matter, depend upon it she is at the Bottom of it. I'll be hang'd if this Ghost be not one of Abigal's Familiars.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Mrs. Abigal has of late been very mysterious.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I fancy, Vellum, thou could'st worm it out of her. I know formerly there was an Amour between you.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Mrs. Abigal hath her Allurements, and she knows I have pick'd up a Competency in your Ho—nour's Service.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: If thou ha'st, all I ask of thee in return is, that thou would'st immediately renew thy Addresses to her. Coax her up. Thou hast such a Silver Tongue, Vellum, as 'twill be impossible for her to withstand. Besides, she is so very a Woman, that she'll like thee the better for giving her the Pleasure of telling a Secret. In short, wheedle her out of it, and I shall act by the Advice which thou givest me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Mrs. Abigal was never deaf to me, when I talked upon that Subject. I will take an Opportunity of addressing my self to her in the most pathetick Manner.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: In the mean time lock me up in your Office, and bring me word what Success you have—Well, sure I am the first that ever was employ'd to lay himself.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: You act indeed a threefold Part in this House; you are a Ghost, a Conjurer, and my Ho—noured Master Sir George Truman; he, he, he! You will pardon me for being jocular.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: O, Mr. Vellum, with all my Heart. You know I love you Men of Wit and Humour. Be as merry as thou pleasest, so thou do'st thy Business. [Mimicking him.] You will remember, Vellum, your Commission is two-fold, first to gain Admission for me to your Lady, and secondly to get the Secret out of Abigal.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It sufficeth.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Women who have been happy in a first Marriage, are the most apt to venture upon a second. But for my part, I had a Husband so every way suited to my Inclinations, that I must entirely forget him, before I can like another Man. I have now been a Widow but fourteen Months, and have had twice as many Lovers, all of 'em profest Admirers of my Person, but passionately in love with my Jointure. I think it is a Revenge I owe my Sex to make an Example of this worthless Tribe of Fellows, who grow impudent, dress themselves fine, and fancy we are oblig'd to provide for 'em. But of all my Captives, Mr. Tinsel is the most extraordinary in his kind. I hope the Diversion I give my self with him is unblameable. I'm sure 'tis necessary to turn my Thoughts off from the Memory of that dear Man, who has been the greatest Happiness and Affliction of my Life. My Heart would be a Prey to Melancholy, if I did not find these innocent Methods of relieving it. But here comes Abigal. I must teaze the Baggage, for I find she has taken it into her Head that I am entirely at her Disposal.

sp.speaker: Ab
sp.p: Madam! Madam! yonder's Mr. Tinsel has as good as taken Possession of your House. Marry, he says, he must have Sir George's Apartment enlarg'd; for truly, says he, I hate to be straiten'd. Nay, he was so impudent as to shew me the Chamber where he intends to consummate, as he calls it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well! he's a wild Fellow.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Indeed he's a very sad Man, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He's young, Abigal; 'tis a thousand Pities he should be lost; I should be mighty glad to reform him.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Reform him! marry hang him!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Has not he a great deal of Life?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ay, enough to make your Heart ake.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I dare say thou think'st him a very agreeable Fellow.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: He thinks himself so, I'll answer for him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He's very good-natur'd!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: He ought to be so, for he's very silly.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dost thou think he loves me?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Mr. Fantome did I am sure.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With what Raptures he talk'd!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Yes, but 'twas in Praise of your Jointure-House.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He has kept bad Company.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: They must be very bad indeed, if they were worse than himself.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have a strong Fancy a good Woman might reform him.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: It wou'd be a fine Experiment, if it shou'd not succeed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, Abigal, we'll talk of that another time; here comes the Steward, I have no further Occasion for you at present.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Madam, is your Ho—nour at Leisure to look into the Accounts of the last Week? They rise very high—House-keeping is chargeable in a House that is haunted.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How comes that to pass? I hope the Drum neither eats nor drinks? But read your Account, Vellum.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: [putting on and off his Spectacles in this Scene] A Hogshead and a Half of Ale—it is not for the Ghost's Drinking—But your Ho—nour's Servants say they must have something to keep up their Courage against this strange Noise. They tell me they expect a double Quantity of Malt in their Small-Beer so long as the House continues in this Condition.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: At this rate they'll take care to be frighten'd all the Year round, I'll answer for 'em. But go on.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p:
Item, Two Sheep, and a—Where is the Ox?—Oh, here I have him—and an Ox—Your Ho—nour must always have a Piece of cold Beef in the House for the Entertainment of so many Strangers, who come from all Parts to hear
this Drum. Item, Bread, ten Peck-Loaves—They cannot eat Beef without Bread—Item, three Barrels of Table Beer—They must have Drink with their Meat.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sure no Woman in England has a Steward that makes such ingenious Comments on his Works. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Item, to Mr. Tinsel's Servants five Bottles of Port Wine—It was by your Ho—nour's Order—Item, three Bottles of Sack for the use of Mrs. Abigal.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I suppose that was by Your own Order.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: We have been long Friends, we are your Ho—nour's Ancient Servants, Sack is an Innocent Cordial, and gives her Spirit to chide the Servants, when they are tardy in their Bus'ness; he, he, he! pardon me for being Jocular.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, I see you'll come together at last.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Item, a dozen Pound of Watch-Lights for the Use of the Servants.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For the Use of the Servants! What, are the Rogues afraid of sleeping in the Dark? What an unfortunate Woman am I! This is such a particular Distress, it puts me to my Wits End. Vellum, what wou'd you advise me to do?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Madam, your Ho—nour has two Points to consider. Imprimis, To retrench these Extravagant Expences, which so many Strangers bring upon you.—Secondly, To clear the House of this Invisible Drummer

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This learned Division leaves me just as wise as I was. But how must we bring these two Points to bear?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I beseech your Ho—nour to give me the hearing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I do. But prithee take pity on me, and be not tedious.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I will be concise. There is a certain Person arrived this Morning, an aged Man of a venerable Aspect, and of a long hoary Beard, that reacheth down to his Girdle. The common People call him a Wizard, a White-Witch, a Conjurer, a Cunning-Man, a Necromancer, a—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No matter for his Titles. But what of all this?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Give me the hearing, good my Lady! he pretends to great Skill in the Occult Sciences, and is come hither upon the rumor of this Drum. If one may believe him, he knows the Secret of laying Ghosts, or of quieting Houses that are haunted.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pho, these are Idle Stories to amuse the Country People, this can do us no good.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It can do us no harm, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I dare say thou do'st not believe there is any thing in it thy self.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I cannot say, I do; there is no danger however in the Experiment. Let him try his Skill; if it shou'd succeed, we are rid of the Drum; if it shou'd not, we may tell the World that it has, and by that means at least get out of this Expensive way of living; so that it must turn to your Advantage one way or another.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I think you argue very rightly. But where is the Man? I would fain see him. He must be a Curiosity.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I have already discours'd him, and he is to be with me, in my Office, half an Hour hence. He asks nothing for his Pains, till he has done his Work;—no Cure, no Mony.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That Circumstance, I must confess, wou'd make one believe there is more in his Art than one wou'd imagine. Pray Vellum go and fetch him hither immediately.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I am gone. He shall be forth-coming forthwith.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Rare News, my Lads, rare News!

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: What's the Matter? hast thou got any more Vales for us?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: No, 'tis better than that.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Is there another Stranger come to the House?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Ay, such a Stranger as will make all our Lives easy.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: What! is he a Lord?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: A Lord! No, nothing like it,—He's a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: A Conjurer! what, is he come a wooing to my Lady?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: No, no, you Fool, he's come a purpose to lay the Spirit.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Ay marry that's good News indeed; But where is he?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: He's lock'd up with the Steward in his Office, they are laying their Heads together very close. I fancy they are casting a Figure.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Prithee John, what sort of a Creature is a Conjurer?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why he's made much as other Men are, if it was not for his long grey Beard.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Look ye Peter, it stands with reason, that a Conjurer shou'd have a long grey Beard—for did ye ever know a Witch that was not an Old Woman?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Why! I remember a Conjurer once at a Fayr, that to my thinking was a very Smock-fac'd Man, and yet he spew'd out fifty Yards of green Ferret. I fancy, John, if thou'dst get him into the Pantry and give him a Cup of Ale, he'd shew us a few Tricks. Do'st think we cou'd not persuade him to swallow one of thy Case-Knives for his Diversion? He'll certainly bring it up again.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Peter! thou art such a Wise-acre! Thou do'st not know the Difference between a Conjurer and a Jugler. This Man must be a very great Master of his Trade. His Beard is at least half a Yard long, he's dress'd in a strange dark Cloak, as black as a Cole, your Conjurer always goes in Mourning.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Is he a Gentleman, had he a Sword by his Side?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: No, no, he's too grave a Man for that, a Conjurer is as grave as a Judge,—but he had a long white Wand in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: You may be sure there's a good deal of Vertue in that Wand—I fancy 'tis made out of Witch Elm.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I warrant you if the Ghost appears, he'll whisk ye that Wand before his Eyes, and strike you the Drum-stick out of his Hand.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: No; the Wand, look ye, is to make a Circle, and if he once gets the Ghost in a Circle, then he has him—let him get out again if he can. A Circle, you must know, is a Conjurer's Trap.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: But what will he do with him, when he has him there?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why then he'll overpower him with his Learning.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: If he can once compass him, and get him in Lobs-Pound, he'll make nothing of him, but speak a few hard Words to him, and perhaps bind him over to his good Behaviour, for a Thousand Years.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Ay, ay, hell send him packing to his Grave again with a Flea in his Ear, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: No, no, I wou'd advise Madam to spare no Cost. If the Conjurer be but well paid, he'll take pains upon the Ghost, and lay him, look ye, in the Red-Sea—and then he's laid for ever.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Ay marry, that wou'd spoil his Drum for him.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Why John, there must be a power of Spirits in that same Red-Sea—I warrant ye they are as plenty as Fish.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Well, I wish after all that he may not be too hard for the Conjurer; I'm afraid he'll find a tough bit of work on't.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I wish the Spirit may not carry a Corner of the House off with him.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: As for that, Peter, you may be sure that the Steward has made his Bargain with the Cunning-Man beforehand, that he shall stand to all Costs, and Damages—But hark! yonder's Mrs. Abigal, we shall have her with us immediately, if we do not get off.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Ay Lads! if we could get Mrs. Abigal well laid too—we should lead merry Lives.
sp.l: For to a Man like me that's Stout and Bold,
A Ghost is not so dreadful as a Scold.

div1.head: ACT III. SCENE I.
div1.stage: SCENE opens, and discovers Sir George in Vellum's Office.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I Wonder I don't hear of Vellum yet. But I know his Wisdom will do nothing rashly. The Fellow has been so us'd to Form in Business, that it has infected his whole Conversation. But I must not find Fault with that punctual and exact Behaviour which has been of so much Use to me; my Estate is the better for it.
Well Vellum, I'm impatient to hear your Success.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: First, let me lock the Door.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Will your Lady admit me?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: If this Lock is not mended soon, it will be quite spoiled.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Prithee let the Lock alone at present, and answer me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Delays in Business are dangerous—I must send for the Smith next Week—and in the mean time will take a minute of it.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: But what says your Lady?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: This Pen is naught, and wants mending—My Lady, did you say?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Does she admit me?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I have gain'd Admission for you as a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: That's enough! I'll gain admission for my self as a Husband. Does she believe there's any thing in my Art?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It is hard to know what a Woman believes.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Did she ask no Questions about me?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Sundry.—She desires to talk with you her self, before you enter upon your Business.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: But when?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Immediately. This Instant.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Pugh. What hast thou been doing all this while! Why didst not tell me so? Give me my Cloak—Have you yet met with Abigal?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I have not yet had an Opportunity of talking with her. But we have interchanged some languishing Glances.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p:
Let thee alone for that Vellum, I have formerly seen thee ogle her through thy Spectacles. Well! This is a most
Venerable Cloak. After the business of this Day is over, I'll make thee a Present of it. 'Twill become thee mightily.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: He, he, he! wou'd you make a Conjurer of your Steward?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Prithee don't be Jocular, I'm in haste. Help me on with my Beard.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: And what will your Ho—nour do with your cast Beard?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Why, faith, thy Gravity wants only such a Beard to it; if thou would'st wear it with the Cloak, thou woud'st make a most compleat Heathen Philosopher. But where's my Wand?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: A fine taper Stick! It is well chosen. I will keep this till you are Sheriff of the County. It is not my custome to let any thing be lost.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Come Vellum, lead the way. You must introduce me to your Lady. Thou'rt the fittest Fellow in the World to be a Master of the Ceremonies to a Conjurer.

div1.stage: Enter Abigal crossing the Stage, Tinsel following.

sp.speaker: Tinsel.
sp.p: Nabby, Nabby, whither so fast Child?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Keep your Hands to your self. I'm going to call the Steward to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: What? Goodman Two fold? I met him walking with a strange old Fellow yonder. I suppose he belongs to the Family too. He looks very antique. He must be some of the Furniture of this old Mansion-House.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: What does the Man mean? Don't think to palm me, as you do my Lady.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Prithee, Nabby, tell me one thing; What's the reason thou art my Enemy?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Marry, because I'm a Friend to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Dost thou see any thing about me thou dost not like? Come hither, Hussy, give me a Kiss. Don't be ill-natur'd.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Sir, I know how to be civil. [Kisses her.]—This Rogue will carry off my Lady, if I don't take care. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Thy Lips are as soft as Velvet, Abigal. I must get thee a Husband.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ay, now you don't speak idly, I can talk to you.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I have one in my Eye for thee. Dost thou love a young lusty Son of a Whore?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Laud, how you talk!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: This is a thundering Dog.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: A private Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ay! where does he live?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: In the Horse-Guards—But he has one Fault I must tell thee of. If thou canst bear with that, he's a Man for thy purpose.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Tinsel, what may that be?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: He's but five and twenty Years Old.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for his Age, if he has been well educated.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: No Man better, Child; he'll tye a Wigg, toss a Die, make a Pass, and swear with such a Grace, as wou'd make thy Heart leap to hear him.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Half these Accomplishments will do, provided he has an Estate—Pray what has he?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Not a Farthing.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Pax on him, what do I give him the hearing for! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: But as for that I wou'd make it up to him.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Why look ye, Child, as soon as I have married thy Lady, I design to discard this old Prig of a Steward, and to put this honest Gentleman, I am speaking of, into his place.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: [aside.] This Fellow's a Fool—I'll have no more to say to him.—Hark! my Lady's a coming!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Depend upon it, Nab, I'll remember my Promise.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ay, and so will I too—to your Cost. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: My Dear is purely fitted up with a Maid—But I shall rid the House of her.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Tinsel, I am glad to meet you here. I am going to give you an Entertainment, that won't be disagreeable to a Man of Wit and Pleasure of the Town—There may be something diverting in a Conversation between a Conjurer, and this conceited Ass. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: She loves me to Distraction, I see that. [Aside.]—Prithee, Widow, explain thy self.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You must know here is a strange sort of a Man come to Town, who undertakes to free the House from this Disturbance. The Steward believes him a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Ay! thy Steward is a deep one!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He's to be here immediately. It is indeed an odd Figure of a Man.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Oh! I warrant you he has study'd the Black Art! Ha, ha, ha! Is not it an Oxford Scholar?—Widow, thy House is the most extraordinarily inhabited of any Widow's this Day in Christendom.—I think thy four chief Domesticks are—a wither'd Abigal—a superannuated Steward,—a Ghost—and a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: [Mimicking Tinsel] And you wou'd have it inhabited by a Fifth, who is a more extraordinary Person than any of all these Four.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: It's a sure Sign a Woman loves you, when she imitates your Manner. [aside]—Thou'rt very smart, my Dear. But, see! smoak the Doctor.

div1.stage: Enter Vellum, and Sir George in his Conjurer's Habit.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I will introduce this profound Person to your Ladyship, and then leave him with you—Sir, this is her Ho—nour.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I know it well.

[Aside, walking in a musing Posture] That dear Woman! The Sight of her un-mans me. I cou'd weep for Tenderness, did not I, at the same time, feel an Indignation rise in me, to see that Wretch with her: And yet I cannot but smile to see her in the Company of her first and second Husband at the same time.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mr. Tinsel do You speak to him; you are us'd to the Company of Men of Learning.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Old Gentleman, thou dost not look like an Inhabitant of this World; I suppose thou art lately come down from the Stars. Pray what News is stirring in the Zodiack?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: News that ought to make the Heart of a Coward tremble. Mars is now entring into the first House, and will shortly appear in all his Domal Dignities—

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Mars? Prithee Father Grey-beard explain thy self.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: The Entrance of Mars into his House, portends the Entrance of a Master into this Family—and that soon.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: D'ye hear that, Widow? The Stars have cut me out for thy Husband. This House is to have a Master, and that soon—Hark thee, old Gadbury, Is not Mars very like a young Fellow call'd Tom Tinsel?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Not so much as Venus is like this Lady.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: A Word in your Ear, Doctor; these two Planets will be in Conjunction by and by; I can tell you that.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: [aside, walking disturb'd] Curse on this impertinent Fop! I shall scarce forbear discovering my self—Madam, I am told that your House is visited with strange Noises.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And I am told that you can quiet them. I must confess I had a Curiosity to see the Person I had heard so much of; and, indeed, your Aspect shows that you have had much Experience in the World. You must be a very aged Man.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: My Aspect deceives you; What do you think is my real Age?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I shou'd guess thee within three Years of Methuselah. Prithee tell me, Was't not thou born before the Flood?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Truly I shou'd guess you to be in your second or third Century. I warrant you, you have Great Grand-children with Beards of a Foot long.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! If there be Truth in Man, I was but five and thirty last August. O! the Study of the Occult Sciences makes a Man's Beard grow faster than you wou'd imagine.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What an Escape you have had, Mr. Tinsel, that you were not bred a Scholar!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: And so I fancy, Doctor, thou think'st me an illiterate Fellow, because I have a smooth Chin?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Hark ye, Sir, a Word in your Ear. You are a Coxcomb, by all the Rules of Physiognomy: But let that be a Secret between you and me. [Aside to Tinsel.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Tinsel, what is it the Doctor whispers?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Only a Compliment, Child, upon two or three of my Features. It does not become Me to repeat it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Doctor, examine this Gentleman's Face, and tell me his Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: If I may believe the Lines of his Face, he likes it better than I do, or—than you do, fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Widow, I hope now thou'rt convinc'd he's a Cheat.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For my part I believe he's a Witch—go on Doctor.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: He will be cross'd in Love; and that soon.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Prithee, Doctor, tell us the Truth. Dost not thou live in Moor-Fields?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Take my Word for it, thou shalt never live in my Lady Truman's Mansion-House.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Pray, old Gentleman, hast thou never been pluck'd by the Beard when thou wert saucy?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay Mr. Tinsel, you are angry! do you think I wou'd marry a Man that dares not have his Fortune told?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Let him be angry—I matter not—He is but liv'd. He will soon die of—

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Come, come, speak out, old Hocus, he, he, he! this Fellow makes me burst with Laughing.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: He will soon die of a Fright—or of the—let me see your Nose—Ay—'tis so!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: You Son of a Whore! I'll run ye through the Body. I never yet made the Sun shine through a Conjurer—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, fy. Mr. Tinsel! you will not kill an old Man?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: An old Man! The Dog says he's but Five and thirty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, fy; Mr. Tinsel, I did not think you could have been so passionate; I hate a passionate Man. Put up your Sword, or I must never see you again.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I was but in jest, my Dear. I had a mind to have made an Experiment upon the Doctor's Body. I wou'd but have drill'd a little Eyelet-hole in it, and have seen whether he had Art enough to close it up again.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Courage is but ill shown before a Lady. But know, if ever I meet thee again, thou shalt find this Arm can wield other Weapons besides this Wand.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, learned Sir, you are to give a Proof of your Art, not of your Courage. Or if you will show your Courage, let it be at Nine a Clock—for that is the time the Noise is generally heard.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: And look ye, old Gentleman, if thou dost not do thy Business well, I can tell thee by the little Skill I have, that thou wilt be toss'd in a Blanket before Ten. We'll do our Endeavour to send thee back to the Stars again.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I'll go and prepare my self for the Ceremonies—And, Lady, as you expect they shou'd succeed to your Wishes, treat that Fellow with the Contempt he deserves.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: The sauciest Dog I ever talk'd with in my whole Life!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Methinks he's a diverting Fellow; one may see he's no Fool.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: No Fool! Ay but thou dost not take him for a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Truly I don't know what to take him for; I am resolv'd to employ him however. When a Sickness is desperate, we often try Remedies that we have no great Faith in.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Madam, the Tea is ready in the Parlour as you ordered.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Tinsel, we may there talk of this Subject more at leisure.

Sure never any Lady had such Servants as mine has! Well, if I get this Thousand Pound, I hope to have some of my own. Let me see, I'll have a pretty tight Girl—just such as I was ten Years ago (I'm afraid I may say twenty) she shall dress me and flatter me—for I will be flatter'd, that's pos! My Lady's cast Suits will serve her after I have given them the wearing. Besides, when I am worth a Thousand Pound, I shall certainly carry off the Steward—Madam Vellum!—how prettily that will sound! here, bring out Madam Vellum's Chaise—Nay I do not know but it may be a Chariot—It will break the Attorney's Wife's Heart—for I shall take place of every Body in the Parish but my Lady. If I have a Son, he shall be call'd Fantome. But see Mr. Vellum, as I could wish. I know his Humour, and will do my utmost to gain his Heart.

div1.stage: Enter Vellum with a Pint of Sack.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Mrs. Abigal, don't I break in upon you unseasonably?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh, No, Mr. Vellum, your Visits are always seasonable.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I have brought with me a Taste of fresh Canary, which I think is delicious.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Pray set it down—I have a Dram-Glass just by—
I'll pledge you; my Lady's good Health.

sp.speaker: Vel
sp.p: And your own with it—sweet Mrs Abigal.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Pray, good Mr. Vellum, buy me a little Parcel of this Sack, and put it under the Article of Tea—I would not have my Name appear to it.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Mrs. Abigal, your Name seldom appears in my Bills—and yet—if you will allow me a merry Expression—You have been always in my Books, Mrs. Abigal. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Mr. Vellum, you are such a dry jesting Man!

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Why truly, Mrs. Abigal, I have been looking over my Papers—and I find you have been a long time my Debtor.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Your Debtor! For what, Mr. Vellum?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: For my Heart, Mrs. Abigal—And our Accounts will not be balanc'd between us, 'till I have yours in Exchange for it. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You are the most gallant Dun, Mr. Vellum.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: But I am not us'd to be paid by Words only, Mrs. Abigal; when will you be out of my Debt?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Vellum, you make one blush—My humble Service to you.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I must answer you, Mrs. Abigal, in the Country Phrase—Your Love is sufficient. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Well, I must own I love a merry Man!

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Let me see, how long is it, Mrs. Abigal, since I first broke my Mind to you—It was, I think, Undecimo Gulielmi—We have convers'd together these fifteen Years—and yet, Mrs. Abigal, I must drink to our better Acquaintance. He, he, he—Mrs. Abigal, you know I am naturally jocose.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ah, you Men love to make Sport with us silly Creatures.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Mrs. Abigal, I have a Trifle about me, which I wou'd willingly make you a Present of. It is indeed but a little Toy.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: You are always exceedingly obliging.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It is but a little Toy—scarce worth your Acceptance.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Pray do not keep me in Suspence; what is it, Mr. Vellum?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: A Silver Thimble.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I always said Mr. Vellum was a generous Lover.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: But I must put it on my self, Mrs. Abigal—You have the prettiest Tip of a Finger—I must take the Freedom to salute it.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh fye! you make me asham'd, Mr. Vellum; how can you do so? I protest I am in such a Confusion—

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: This Finger is not the Finger of Idleness; it bears the honourable Scars of the Needle—But why are you so cruel as not to pare your Nails?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh, I vow you press it so hard! pray give me my Finger again.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: This Middle Finger, Mrs. Abigal, has a pretty Neighbour—A Wedding Ring would become it mightily——He, he, he.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: You're so full of your Jokes. Ay, but where must I find one for it?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I design this Thimble only as the Forerunner of it, they will set off each other, and are—indeed a twofold Emblem. The first will put you in mind of being a good Huswife, and the other of being a good Wife. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I see you laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Indeed I am serious.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I thought you had quite forsaken me—I am sure you cannot forget the many repeated Vows and Promises you formerly made me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I shou'd as soon forget the Multiplication Table.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I have always taken your part before may Lady.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: You have so, and I have Item'd it in my Memory.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: For I have always look'd upon your Interest as my own.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It is nothing but your Cruelty can hinder them from being so.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I must strike while the Iron's hot. [Aside.]—Well, Mr. Vellum, there is no refusing you, you have such a bewitching Tongue!

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: How? Speak that again!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Why then in plain English I love you.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I'm Overjoy'd!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I must own my Passion for you,

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I'm Transported!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Dear Charming Man!

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Thou Summ Total of all my Happiness! I shall grow Extravagant! I can't forbear!—to drink thy vertuous Inclinations in a Bumper of Sack. Your Lady must make haste, my Duck, or we shall provide a young Steward to the Estate, before she has an Heir to it—prithee my Dear, doe's she intend to Marry Mr. Tinsel?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p:
Marry him! my Love, No, no! we must take care of that! there wou'd be no staying in the House for us if she did. That young Rake-hell wou'd send all the old Servants a Grazing.
You and I shou'd be discarded before the Honey Moon was at an End.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Prithee, sweet one, does not this Drum put the Thoughts of Marriage out of her Head?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: This Drum, my Dear, if it be well manag'd, will be no less than a Thousand Pound in our way.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Ay, sayst thou so, my Turtle?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Since we are now as good as Man and Wife—I mean, almost as good as Man and Wife—I ought to conceal nothing from you.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Certainly my Dove, not from thy Yoke-Fellow, thy Help-Mate, thy own Flesh and Blood!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Hush! I hear Mr. Tinsel's Laugh, my Lady and he are a coming this way; if you will take a turn without, I'll tell you the whole Contrivance.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Give me your Hand, Chicken.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Here take it, you have my Heart already.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: We shall have much Issue.

div1.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: JOHN, I have certain Orders to give you—and therefore be attentive.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Attentive! Ay, let me alone for that.—I suppose he means being Sober. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: You know I have always recommended to you a Method in your Business, I wou'd have your Knives and Forks, your Spoons and Napkins, your Plate and Glasses, laid in a Method.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Ah, Master Vellum, you are such a sweet-spoken Man, it does one's Heart good to receive your Orders.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Method, John, makes Business easie, it banishes all Perplexity and Confusion out of Families.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: How he talks! I cou'd hear him all Day.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: And now John, let me know whether your Table-linnen, your Side-Board, your Cellar, and every thing else within your Province, are properly and methodically dispos'd for an Entertainment this Evening.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Master Vellum, they shall be ready at a quarter of an hour's Warning. But pray Sir, is this Entertainment to be made for the Conjurer?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It is, John, for the Conjurer, and yet it is not for the Conjurer.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why, look you Master Vellum, if it is for the Conjurer, the Cook-Maid shou'd have Orders to get him some Dishes to his Palate. Perhaps he may like a little Brimstone in his Sauce.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: This Conjurer, John, is a complicated Creature, an Amphibious Animal, a Person of a Two-fold Nature—But he eats and drinks like other Men.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Marry, Master Vellum, he shou'd eat and drink as much as two other Men, by the Account you give of him.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Thy Conceit is not amiss, he is indeed a double Man, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Ha! I understand you, He's one of your Hermaphrodites, as they call 'em.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: He is Married, and he is not Married—He hath a Beard, and he hath no Beard. He is Old, and he is Young.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: How charmingly he talks! I fancy, Master Vellum, you cou'd make a Riddle. The same Man Old and Young! How do you make that out, Master Vellum?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Thou hast heard of a Snake casting his Skin, and recovering his Youth. Such is this Sage Person.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Nay 'tis no wonder a Conjurer shou'd be like a Serpent.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: When he has thrown aside the old Conjurer's Slough that hangs about him, he'll come out as fine a young Gentleman as ever was seen in this House.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Does he intend to sup in his Slough?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: That Time will show.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Well, I have not a Head for these things. Indeed, Mr. Vellum, I have not understood one Word you have said this half Hour.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I did not intend thou shou'dst—But to our Business—Let there be a Table spread in the Great-Hall. Let your Pots and Glasses be wash'd, and in a Readiness. Bid the Cook provide a plentiful Supper, and see that all the Servants be in their best Liveries.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Ay! now I understand every Word you say. But I wou'd rather hear you talk a little in that t'other Way.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I shall explain to thee what I have said by and by—Bid Susan lay two Pillows upon your Lady's Bed.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Two Pillows! Madam won't sleep upon 'em both! She is not a double Woman too?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: She will sleep upon neither. But hark, Mrs. Abigal, I think I hear her chiding the Cook-Maid.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Then I'll away, or it will be my Turn next; She, I am sure, speaks plain English, one may easily understand every Word She says.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Servants are good for nothing, unless they have an Opinion of the Person's Understanding who has the Direction of them.—But see Mrs. Abigal! she has a bewitching Countenance, I wish I may not be tempted to marry her in good Earnest.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ha! Mr. Vellum.

sp.speaker: Vel
sp.p: What brings my Sweet one hither?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I am coming to speak to my Friend behind the Wainscot. It is fit, Child, he shou'd have an Account of this Conjurer, that he may not be surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: That wou'd be as much as thy thousand Pound is worth.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I'll speak low—Walls have Ears. [Pointing at the Wainscot.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: But heark you Ducklin! be sure you do not tell him that I am let into the Secret.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: That's a good one indeed! as if I shou'd ever tell what passes between you and me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: No, no, my Child, that must not be; he, he, he! that must not be; he, he, he!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: You will always be waggish.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Adieu, and let me hear the result of your Conference.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: How can you leave one so soon? I shall think it an Age till I see you again.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Adieu my pretty one.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Adieu sweet Mr. Vellum.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: My pretty one.— [As he is going off.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Vellum!

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: My pretty one!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: I have him—if I can but get this Thousand Pound.
sp.stage: [Fantome gives three Raps upon his Drum behind the Wainscot.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ha. Three Raps upon the Drum! the Signal Mr. Fantome and I agreed upon, when he had a mind to speak with me.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Very well, I hear you; come Fox, come out of your Hole.

div1.stage: Scene opens, and Fantome comes out.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: You may leave your Drum in the Ward-robe, till you have Occasion for it.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Well, Mrs. Abigal, I want to hear what is a doing in the World.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: You are a very inquisitive Spirit. But I must tell you, if you do not take care of your self, you will be Laid this Evening.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p:
I have overheard something of that Matter. But let me alone for the Doctor—I'll engage to give a good Account of
Him. I am more in pain about Tinsel. When a Lady's in the Case, I'm more afraid of one Fop than twenty Conjurers.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: To tell you truly, he presses his Attacks with so much Impudence, that he has made more Progress with my Lady in two Days, than you did in two Months.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: I shall attack her in another manner, if thou canst but procure me another Interview. There's nothing makes a Lover so keen, as being kept up in the Dark.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Pray no more of your distant Bows, your respectful Compliments—Realy, Mr. Fantome, you're only fit to make Love a-cross a Tea-Table.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: My dear Girl, I can't forbear hugging thee for thy good Advice.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ay, now I have some Hopes of you; but why don't you do so to my Lady?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Child, I always thought your Lady lov'd to be treated with Respect.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Believe me, Mr. Fantome, there is not so great a difference between Woman and Woman, as you imagine. You see Tinsel has nothing but his Sauciness to recommend him.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Tinsel is too great a Coxcomb to be capable of Love—And let me tell thee, Abigal, a Man, who is sincere in his Passion, makes but a very awkard Profession of it—But I'll mend my Manners.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ay, or you'll never gain a Widow—Come, I must tutor you a little; suppose me to be my Lady, and let me see how you'll behave your self.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: I'm afraid, Child, we han't time for such a piece of Mummery.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh, it will be quickly over, if you play your Part well.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Why then, dear Mrs. Ab—I mean my Lady Truman.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ay! but you han't saluted me.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: That's right; Faith I forgot that Circumstance. [Kisses her.] Nectar and Ambrosia!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: That's very well—

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: How long must I be condemn'd to languish! when shall my Sufferings have an end! My Life! my Happiness, my All is wound up in you—

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Well! why don't you squeeze my Hand?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: What, thus?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Thus? Ay—Now throw your Arm about my Middle; Hug me closer.—You are not afraid of hurting me! Now pour forth a Volley of Rapture and Nonsense, till you are out of Breath.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Transport and Extasy! where am I!—my Life, my Bliss!—I rage, I burn, I bleed, I dye.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Go on, go on.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Flames and Darts—Bear me to the gloomy Shade, Rocks and Grottoes—Flowers, Zephyrs, and purling Streams.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Fantome, you have a Tongue wou'd undo a Vestal! You were born for the Ruin of our Sex.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: This will do then, Abigal?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Ay, this is talking like a Lover. Tho' I only represent my Lady, I take a Pleasure in hearing you. Well, o' my Conscience when a Man of Sense has a little Dash of the Coxcomb in him, no Woman can resist him. Go on at this rate, and the thousand Pound is as good as in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: I shall think it an Age till I have an Opportunity of putting this Lesson in Practice.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: You may do it soon, if you make good Use of your Time; Mr. Tinsel will be here with my Lady at Eight, and at Nine the Conjurer is to take you in Hand.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Let me alone with both of them.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Well! fore-warn'd, fore-arm'd. Get into your Box, and I'll endeavour to dispose every thing in your Favour.

sp.speaker: Vel.
