sp.p: Mrs. Abigal is withdrawn.—I was in hopes to have heard what pass'd between her and her invisible Correspondent.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: [aside.] Vellum! We are methinks very familiar; I am not us'd to be call'd so by any but their Ho—nours—What wou'd you, Mr. Tinsel?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Let me beg a Favour of thee, old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: What is that, good Sir?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Prithee run and fetch me the Rent-Roll of thy Lady's Estate.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: The Rent-roll?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: The Rent-roll? Ay, the Rent-roll! Dost not understand what that means?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Why? have you Thoughts of purchasing of it?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Thou hast hit it, old Boy; that is my very Intention.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: The Purchase will be considerable.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: And for that reason I have bid thy Lady very high—She is to have no less for it than this entire Person of mine.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Is your whole Estate Personal, Mr. Tinsel—he, he, he!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Why, you queer old Dog, you don't pretend to jest, d'ye? Look ye, Vellum, if you think of being continued my Steward, you must learn to walk with your Toes out.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: [Aside.] An insolent Companion!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Thou'rt confounded rich, I see, by that Dangling of thy Arms.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: [Aside.] An ungracious Bird!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Thou shalt lend me a couple of Thousand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: [Aside.] A very Profligate!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Look ye, Vellum, I intend to be kind to you—I'll borrow some Mony of you.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I cannot but smile to consider the Disappointment this young Fellow will meet with; I will make my self merry with him. [Aside.] And so, Mr. Tinsel, you promise you will be a very kind Master to me?[Stifling a Laugh.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: What will you give for a Life in the House you live in?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: What do you think of Five Hundred Pounds?—Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: That's too little.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: And yet it is more than I shall give you—And I will offer you two Reasons for it.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Prithee what are they?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: First, because the Tenement is not in your Disposal; and Secondly, because it never will be in your Disposal; and so fare you well, good Mr. Tinsel. Ha, ha, ha! You will pardon me for being jocular.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: This Rogue is as saucy as the Conjurer; I'll be hang'd if they are not a-kin.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mr. Tinsel! what, all alone? You Free-thinkers are great Admirers of Solitude.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: No faith, I have been talking with thy Steward; a very grotesque Figure of a Fellow, the very Picture of one of our Benchers. How can you bear his Conversation?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I keep him for my Steward, and not my Companion. He's a sober Man.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he looks like a Put—a queer old Dog, as ever I saw in my Life: We must turn him off, Widow. He cheats thee confoundedly, I see that.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed you're mistaken, he has always had the Reputation of being a very honest Man.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: What? I suppose he goes to Church.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Goes to Church! so do you too, I hope.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I wou'd for once, Widow, to make sure of you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Tinsel, a Husband who would not continue to go thither, wou'd quickly forget the Promises he made there.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Faith very innocent and very ridiculous! Well then, I warrant thee, Widow, thou wou'dst not for the World marry a Sabbath-breaker!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Truly they generally come to a bad End. I remember the Conjurer told you, you were short-liv'd.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: The Conjurer! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed you're very witty!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Indeed you're very handsome.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I wish the Fool does not love me! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Thou art the Idol I adore. Here must I pay my Devotion—Prithee, Widow, hast thou any Timber upon thy Estate?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The most impudent Fellow I ever met with. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I take Notice thou hast a great deal of old Plate here in the House, Widow.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mr. Tinsel, you are a very observing Man.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Thy large Silver Cistern would make a very good Coach, and half a Dozen Salvers that I saw on the Side-board, might be turn'd into six as pretty Horses as any that appear in the Ring.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You have a very good Fancy, Mr. Tinsel—What pretty Transformations you could make in my House—But I'll see where 'twill end. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Then I observe, Child, you have two or three Services of gilt Plate; we'd eat always in China, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I perceive you are an excellent Manager—How quickly you have taken an Inventory of my Goods!

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Now hark ye, Widow, to show you the Love that I have for you—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Very well, let me hear.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: You have an old-fashion'd Gold Caudle-Cup, with the Figure of a Saint upon the Lid on't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have, what then?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Why look ye, I'd sell the Caudle-Cup with the old Saint for as much Money as they'd fetch, which I wou'd convert into a Diamond Buckle, and make you a Present of it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh you are generous to an Extravagance. But pray, Mr. Tinsel, don't dispose of my Goods before you are sure of my Person. I find you have taken a great Affection to my Moveables.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: My Dear, I love every thing that belongs to you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I see you do, Sir, you need not make any Protestations upon that Subject.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Pho, pho, my Dear, we are growing Serious; and, let me tell you, that's the very next Step to being Dull. Come, that pretty Face was never made to look grave with.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir, whatever you may think, Marriage is a serious Subject.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: For that very Reason, my Dear, let us get over it as fast as we can.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I should be very much in haste for a Husband, if I married within fourteen Months after Sir George's Decease.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Pray, my Dear, let me ask you a Question; Do'st not thou think that Sir George is as dead at present, to all Intents and Purposes, as he will be a Twelve-month hence?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, but Decency! Mr. Tinsel—

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Or do'st thou think thou'lt be more a Widow then, than thou art now?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The World would say I never lov'd my First Husband.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Ah, my Dear, they wou'd say you lov'd your Second; and they wou'd own I deserv'd it, for I shall love thee most inordinately.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But what wou'd People think?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Think! why they wou'd think thee the Mirrour of Widowhood.—That a Woman shou'd live fourteen whole Months after the Decease of her Spouse, without having engaged herself. Why, about Town, we know many a Woman of Quality's Second Husband several Years before the Death of the First.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay, I know you Wits have your common-place Jests upon us poor Widows.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I'll tell you a Story, Widow; I know a certain Lady, who considering the Craziness of her Husband, had, in case of Mortality, engaged her self to two young Fellows of my Acquaintance. They grew such desperate Rivals for her, while her Husband was alive, that one of them pink'd the t'other in a Duel. But the good Lady was no sooner a Widow, but what did my Dowager do? Why faith, being a Woman of Honour, she married a Third, to whom, it seems, she had given her first Promise.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And this is a true Story upon your own Knowledge?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Every Tittle, as I hope to be marry'd, or never believe Tom Tinsel.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Tinsel, do you call this talking like a Wit, or like a Rake?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Innocent enough, he, he, he! Why! where's the Difference, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Tinsel, the only Man I ever lov'd in my Life, had a great deal of the one, and nothing of the other in him.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Nay now you grow vapourish; thou'lt begin to fancy thou hear'st the Drum by and by.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If you had been here last Night about this time, you would not have been so merry.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: About this time, say'st thou? Come faith, for the Humour's sake, we'll sit down and listen.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I will, if you'll promise to be serious.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Serious! never fear me, Child. Ha, ha, ha! Do'st not hear him?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You break your World already. Pray, Mr. Tinsel, do you laugh to show your Wit or your Teeth?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Why, both! my Dear.—I'm glad, however, that she has taken notice of my Teeth. [Aside.] But you look serious, Child; I fancy thou hear'st the Drum, do'st not?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Don't talk so rashly?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Why, my Dear, you cou'd not look more frighted if you had Lucifer's Drum-Major in your House.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mr. Tinsel, I must desire to see you no more in it, if you do not leave this idle way of Talking.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Child, I thought I had told you what is my Opinion of Spirits, as we were drinking a dish of Tea but just now.—There is no such thing I give thee my Word.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Tinsel, your Authority must be of great weight to those that know you.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: For my part, Child, I have made my self easy in those Points.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sure nothing was ever like this Fellow's Vanity, but his Ignorance. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I'll tell thee what now, Widow—I wou'd engage by the help of a white Sheet and a penny-worth of Link in a dark Night, to frighten you a whole Country Village out of their Sences, and the Vicar into the bargain. [Drum beats.] Hark! hark! what Noise is that! Heaven defend us! this is more than Fancy.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: It beats more terrible than ever.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: 'Tis very dreadful! What a Dog have I been to speak against my Conscience, only to show my Parts!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: It comes nearer and nearer. I wish you have not anger'd it by your foolish Discourse.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, I did not speak from my Heart; I hope it will do me no hurt, for a little harmless Raillery.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Harmless, d'ye call it? it beats hard by us, as if it wou'd break through the Wall.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: What a Devil had I to do with a white Sheet?

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Mercy on us! it appears.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis he! 'tis he himself, 'tis Sir George! 'tis my Husband.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: Now wou'd I give Ten Thousand Pound that I were in Town.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p: I beg Ten Thousand Pardons. I'll never talk at this rate any more.

sp.speaker: Tin.
sp.p:
By my Soul, Sir George, I was not in earnest [falls on his knees] have Compassion on my Youth, and consider I am but a Coxcomb— [Fantome points to the Door.] But see he
waves me off—ay with all my Heart—What a Devil had I to do with a white Sheet?
sp.stage: [He steals off the Stage, mending his Pace as the Drum beats.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: The Scoundrel is gone, and has left his Mistress behind him. I'm mistaken if he makes Love in this House any more. I have now only the Conjurer to deal with. I don't question but I shall make his Reverence scamper as fast as the Lover. And then the Day's my own. But the Servants are coming. I must get into my Cup-board.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh my poor Lady! This wicked Drum has frighted Mr. Tinsel out of his Wits, and my Lady into a Swoon. Let me bend her a little forward. She revives. Here, carry her into the fresh Air and she'll recover. [They carry her off.] This is a little barbarous to my Lady, but 'tis all for her Good: and I know her so well, that she wou'd not be angry with me, if she knew what I was to get by it. And if any of her Friends shou'd blame me for it hereafter,
sp.l: I'll clap my Hand upon my Purse, and tell 'em,
'Twas for a thousand Pound and Mr. Vellum.

div1.head: ACT V. SCENE I.
div1.stage: Enter Sir George, in his Conjurer's Habit, the Butler marching before him with two large Candles, and the two Servants coming after him, one bringing a little Table, and another a Chair.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: AN't please your Worship, Mr. Conjurer, the Steward has given all of us Orders to do whatsoever you shall bid us, and to pay you the same Respect, as if you were our Master.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Thou say'st well.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: An't please your Conjurership's Worship, shall I set the Table down here?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Here, Peter.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Peter!—He knows my Name by his Learning. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: I have brought you, Reverend Sir, the largest Elbow Chair in the House; 'tis that the Steward sits in when he holds a Court.

sp.speaker: Sir G:
sp.p: Place it there.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir, will you please to want any thing else?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Paper, and a Pen and Ink.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir, I believe we have Paper that is fit for your Purpose! My Lady's mourning Paper, that is black'd at the Edges—Wou'd you chuse to write with a Crow Quill?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: There is none better.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Coachman, go fetch the Paper and Standish out of the little Parlour.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: [To Gard.] Peter, prithee do thou go along with me—I'm afraid—You know I went with you last Night into the Garden, when the Cook-Maid wanted a handful of Parsley.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why, you don't think I'll stay with the Conjurer by my self!

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Come, we'll all three go and fetch the Pen and Ink together.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: There's nothing, I see, makes such strong Alliances as Fear. These Fellows are all enter'd into a Confederacy against the Ghost. There must be abundance of Business done in the Family at this rate. But here comes the Triple-Alliance. Who cou'd have thought these three Rogues cou'd have found each of 'em an Employment in fetching a Pen and Ink!

div1.stage: Enter Gardiner with a Sheet of Paper, Coachman with a Standish, and Butler with a Pen.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Sir, there is your Paper.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Sir, there is your Standish.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir, there is your Crow-quill Pen—I'm glad I have got rid on't. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: [Aside.] He forgets that he's to make a Circle—Doctor, shall I help you to a Bit of Chalk?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: It is no matter.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Look ye, Sir, I show'd you the Spot where he's heard oftenest, if your Worship can but ferret him out of that old Wall in the next Room—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: We shall try.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: That's right, John. His Worship must let fly all his Learning at that old Wall.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir, if I was worthy to advise you, I wou'd have a Bottle of good October by me. Shall I set a Cup of old Stingo at your Elbow?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I thank thee—we shall do without it.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: John, he seems a very good-natur'd Man for a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I'll take this Opportunity of enquiring after a Bit of Plate I have lost. I fancy, whilst he is in my Lady's Pay, one may hedge in a Question or two into the Bargain. Sir, Sir, may I beg a word in your Ear?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: What wouldst thou?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir, I know I need not tell you, that I lost one of my Silver Spoons last Week.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Mark'd with a Swan's Neck—

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: My Lady's Crest! He knows every thing. [Aside.] How wou'd your Worship advise me to recover it again?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Hum!

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: What must I do to come at it?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Drink nothing but Small-Beer for a Fortnight—

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Small Beer! Rot-gut!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: If thou drink'st a single Drop of Ale before fifteen Days are expir'd—it is as much—as thy Spoon—is worth.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I shall never recover it that way; I'll e'en buy a new one. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: D'ye mind how they whisper?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd if he be not asking him something about Nell—

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: I'll take this Opportunity of putting a Question to him about poor Dobbing: I fancy he cou'd give me better Council than the Farrier.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: [to Gard.] A prodigious Man! he knows every thing: Now is the time to find out thy Pick-ax.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I have nothing to give him: Does not he expect to have his Hand cross'd with Silver?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: [to Sir G.] Sir, may a Man venture to ask you a Question?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Ask it.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: I have a poor Horse in the Stable that's bewitch'd—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: A bay Gelding.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: How cou'd he know that?— [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Bought at Banbury.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Whew—so it was o' my Conscience.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Six Year old last Lammas.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: To a Day. [Aside.] Now, Sir, I wou'd know whether the poor Beast is bewitch'd by Goody Crouch or Goody Flye?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Then it must be Goody Gurton! for she is the next oldest Woman in the Parish.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Ha'st thou done, Robin?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: [to Gard.] He can tell thee any thing.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: [to Sir G.] Sir, I wou'd beg to take you a little further out of hearing——

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Speak.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: The Butler and I, Mr. Doctor, were both of us in Love at the same time with a certain Person.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: A Woman.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: How cou'd he know that! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: This Woman has lately had two Children at a Birth.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Twins.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Prodigious! where could he hear that? [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Now, because I us'd to meet her sometimes in the Garden, she has laid them both—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: To Thee.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: What a Power of Learning he must have! he knows every thing. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Ha'st thou done?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: I wou'd desire to know whether I am really Father to them both?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Stand before me, let me survey thee round.
sp.stage: [Lays his Wand upon his Head, and makes him turn about.]

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Look yonder, John, the silly Dog is turning about under the Conjurer's Wand. If he has been saucy to him, we shall see him puff'd off in a Whirlwind immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Twins, do'st thou say?[Still turning him.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Ay, are they both mine d'ye think?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Own but one of them.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Ah, but Mrs. Abigal will have me take care of them both—she's always for the Butler—If my poor Master Sir George had been alive, he wou'd have made him go Halves with me.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: What, was Sir George a kind Master?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Was he! Ay, my Fellow-Servants will bear me Witness.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Did ye love Sir George?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Every Body lov'd him—

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: There was not a dry Eye in the Parish at the News of his Death—

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: He was the best Neighbour—

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: The kindest Husband—

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: The truest Friend to the Poor—

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: My good Lady took on mightily, we all thought it wou'd have been the Death of her——

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I protest these Fellows melt me! I think the time long till I am their Master again, that I may be kind to them. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Have you provided the Doctor ev'ry thing he has Occasion for? if so,—you may depart.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I can as yet see no hurt in my Wife's Behaviour; but still have some certain Pangs and Doubts, that are natural to the Heart of a fond Man. I must take the Advantage of my Disguise to be thoroughly satisfied. It wou'd neither be for her Happiness, nor mine, to make my self known to her till I am so [Aside.] Dear Vellum! I am impatient to hear some News of my Wife, how does she after her Fright?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It is a Saying somewhere in my Lord Coke, that a Widow—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I ask of my Wife, and thou talk'st to me of my Lord Coke—prithee tell me how she does, for I am in Pain for her.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: She is pretty well recover'd Mrs. Abigal has put her in good Heart; and I have given her great hopes from your Skill.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: That I think cannot fail, since thou hast got this Secret out of Abigal! But I could not have thought my Friend Fantome would have served me thus—

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: You will still fancy you are a living Man—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: That he shou'd endeavour to Ensnare my Wife—

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: You have no Right in her, after your Demise Death extinguishes all Property,—Quoad hanc—It is a Maxim in the Law.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: A Pox on your Learning! Well, but what is become of Tinsel?

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: He rush'd out of the House, call'd for his Horse, clap'd Spurs to his sides, and was out of sight in less time, than I—can—tell—ten.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: This is Whimsical enough! my Wife will have a quick Succession of Lovers, in one Day—Fantome has driven out Tinsel, and I shall drive out Fantome.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Ev'n as one Wedge driveth out another—he, he, he! you must pardon me for being Jocular.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Was there ever such a provoking Blockhead! but he means me well.—Well! I must have Satisfaction of this Traitour Fantome; and cannot take a more proper one, than by turning him out of my House, in a manner that shall throw Shame upon him, and make him ridiculous as long as he lives.—You must remember, Vellum, you have abundance of Business upon your Hands, and I have but just time to tell it you over, all I require of you is Dispatch, therefore hear me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: There is nothing more requisite in Business than Dispatch—

sp.speaker: Sir. G.
sp.p: Then hear me.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It is indeed the Life of Business—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Hear Me then, I say.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: And as one has rightly observed, the Benefit that attends it is four-fold. First—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: There is no bearing this! Thou art a going to describe Dispatch, when thou shouldst be practising it.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: But your Ho—nour will not give me the hearing—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Thou wilt not give me the hearing. [Angrily.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: I am still.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: In the First place, you are to lay my Wigg, Hat, and Sword ready for me in the Closet, and one of my Scarlet Coats. You know how Abigal has described the Ghost to you.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Then you must remember, whilst I am laying this Ghost, you are to prepare my Wife for the Reception of her real Husband; tell her the whole Story, and do it with all the Art you are Master of, that the Surprise may not be too great for her.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: It shall be done—But since her Ho—nour has seen this Apparition, she desires to see you once more, before you encounter it.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I shall expect her impatiently. For now I can talk to her without being interrupted by that impertinent Rogue Tinsel. I hope thou hast not told Abigal any thing of the Secret.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.p: Mrs. Abigal is a Woman; there are many Reasons why she shou'd not be acquainted with it: I shall only mention Six—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Hush, here she comes! Oh my Heart!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: [Aside, while Vellum talks in dumb Show to Lady.] O that lov'd Woman! How I long to take her in my Arms! If I find I am still Dear to her Memory, it will be a return to Life indeed! But I must take care of indulging this Tenderness, and put on a Behaviour more suitable to my present Character.
sp.stage: [Walks at a distance in a pensive Posture, waving his Wand.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: [to Vellum.] This is surprizing indeed! So all the Servants tell me; They say he knows every thing that has happen'd in the Family.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: [Aside.] A parcel of credulous Fools! They first tell him their Secrets, and then wonder how he comes to know them.
sp.stage: [Exit Vellum, exchanging fond Looks with Abigal.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Learned Sir, may I have some Conversation with you, before you begin your Ceremonies?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Speak! But hold—first let me feel your Pulse?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What can you learn from that?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I have already learn'd a Secret from it, that will astonish you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, what is it?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: You will have a Husband within this half Hour.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: [Aside.] I'm glad to hear that—He must mean Mr. Fantome; I begin to think there's a good deal of Truth in his Art.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Alas! I fear you mean I shall see Sir George's Apparition a second time.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Have Courage, you shall see the Apparition no more. The Husband I mention shall be as much alive as I am.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Mr. Fantome to be sure. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Impossible! I lov'd my first too well.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: You cou'd not love the first better than you will love the second.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: [Aside.] I'll be hang'd if my dear Steward has not instructed him; he means Mr. Fantome to be sure; the Thousand Pound is our own!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Alas! you did not know Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir G
sp.p: As well as I do my self—I saw him with you in the red Damask Room, when he first made Love to you; your Mother left you together, under Pretence of receiving a Visit from Mrs. Hawthorn, on her Return from London.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This is astonishing!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: You were a great Admirer of a single Life for the first half Hour; your Refusals then grew still fainter and fainter. With what Extasy did Sir George kiss your Hand, when you told him you shou'd always follow the Advice of your Mamma!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Every Circumstance to a Tittle!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Then, Lady! the Wedding Night! I saw you in your white Sattin Night-gown; you wou'd not come out of your Dressing-Room, till Sir George took you out by Force. He drew you gently by the Hand—You struggled—but he was too strong for you—You blush'd, He—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! stop there! go no farther!—He knows every thing. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Truly, Mr. Conjurer, I believe you have been a Wagg in your Youth.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Mrs. Abigal, you know what your good Word cost Sir George, a Purse of Broad Pieces, Mrs. Abigal—

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: The Devil's in him. [Aside.] Pray, Sir, since you have told so far, you should tell my Lady that I refus'd to take them.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Child, he was forc'd to thrust them into your Bosome.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p:
This Rogue will mention the Thousand Pound, if I don't
take care [Aside.] Pray, Sir, tho' you are a Conjurer, methinks you need not be a Blab—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, since I have now no Reason to doubt of your Art, I must beseech you to treat this Apparition gently—It has the resemblance of my deceas'd Husband, if there be any undiscover'd Secret, any thing that troubles his Rest, learn it of him.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I must to that End be sincerely informed by you, whether your Heart be engaged to another; Have not you receiv'd the Addresses of many Lovers since his Death?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have been oblig'd to receive more Visits, than have been agreeable.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Was not Tinsel welcome?—I'm afraid to hear an Answer to my own Question. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He was well recommended.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Racks! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Of a good Family.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Tortures! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Heir to a considerable Estate!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Death! [Aside] And you still love him?—I'm Distracted! [Aside.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, I despise him. I found he had a design upon my Fortune, was Base, Profligate, Cowardly, and ev'ry thing that cou'd be expected from a Man of the vilest Principles!—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I'm Recover'd.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, had you seen how like a Scoundrel he look'd when he left your Ladyship in a Swoon. Where have you left my Lady? says I. In an Elbow-Chair, Child, says he. And where are you going? says I. To Town, Child, says he: For to tell thee truly, Child, says he, I don't care for living under the same Roof with the Devil, says he.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Well, Lady, I see nothing in all this, that may hinder Sir George's Spirit from being at Rest.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: If he knows any thing of what passes in my Heart, he cannot but be satisfy'd of that Fondness which I bear to his Memory. My Sorrow for him is always fresh when I think of him. He was the kindest, truest, tenderest—Tears will not let me go on—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p:
This quite o'erpowers me—I shall discover my self
before my time. [Aside.]—Madam, you may now retire and leave to me my self.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Success attend you!

sp.speaker: Abig.
sp.p: I wish Mr. Fantome gets well off from this old Don—I know he'll be with him immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: My Heart is now at Ease, she is the same dear Woman I left her—Now for my Revenge upon Fantome.—I shall cut the Ceremonies short—A few Words will do his Business—Now let me seat my self in form.—A good easy Chair for a Conjurer this!—Now for a few Mathematical Scratches—a good lucky Scrawl, that—faith I think it looks very Astrological—These two or three magical Pot-hooks about it, make it a compleat Conjurer's Scheme. [Drum beats] Ha, ha, ha, Sir, are you there? Enter Drummer. Now must I pore upon my Paper.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Prithee don't make a Noise, I'm busy.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: A pretty March! prithee beat that over again.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: [Rising] Ha! you're very perfect in the Step of a Ghost. You stalk it Majestically.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: How the Rogue stares, he acts it to Admiration; I'll be hang'd if he has not been practising this half hour in Mrs. Abigal's Wardrobe.
sp.stage: [Fantome starts, gives a rap upon his Drum.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Prithee don't play the Fool!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Nay, nay, enough of this good Mr. Fantome.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: [Aside.] Death! I'm discover'd. This Jade Abigal has betray'd me.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Mr. Fantome, upon the Word of an Astrologer, your Thousand Pound Bribe will never gain my Lady Truman.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: 'Tis plain, She has told him all. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Let me advise you to make off as fast as you can, or I plainly perceive by my Art, Mr. Ghost will have his Bones broke.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: [to Sir G.] Look'ye, Old Gentleman, I perceive you have learnt this Secret from Mrs. Abigal.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I have learn'd it from my Art.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Thy Art! prithee no more of that. Look ye, I know you are a Cheat as much as I am. And if thou'lt keep my Counsel, I'll give thee ten Broad Pieces.—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I am not Mercenary! Young Man, I scorn thy Gold.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: I'll make them up Twenty.—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Avaunt! and that quickly, or I'll raise such an Apparition, as shall—

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: An Apparition, Old Gentleman! you mistake your Man, I am not to be frighten'd with Bugbears.—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Let me retire but for a few Moments, and I will give thee such a Proof of my Art—

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Why, if thou hast any Hocus-pocus Tricks to play, why canst not do them here?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: The raising of a Spirit, requires certain Secret Mysteries to be performed, and Words to be mutter'd in private.—

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Well, if I see through your Trick, will you promise to be my Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: I will—attend and tremble.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: A very solemn old Ass! But I smoak him,—he has a mind to raise his Price upon me. I cou'd not think this Slut wou'd have us'd me thus.—I begin to grow horribly tir'd of my Drum, I wish I was well rid of it. However I have got this by it, that it has driven off Tinsel for good and all; I shan't have the Mortification to see my Mistress carry'd off by such a Rival, Well, whatever happens, I must stop this Old Fellow's Mouth, I must not be sparing in Hush-Money. But here he comes.

div1.stage: Enter Sir George in his own Habit.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Ha! what's that! Sir George Truman! This can be no Counterfeit. His Dress! his Shape! his Face! the very Wound of which he dy'd! Nay, then 'tis time to decamp!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Fare you well, good Sir George—The Enemy has left me Master of the Field: Here are the Marks of my Victory. This Drum will I hang up in my great Hall as the Trophy of the Day.

div1.stage: Sir George stands with his Hand before his Face in a musing Posture.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Yonder he is. O' my Conscience he has driven off the Conjurer. Mr. Fantome, Mr. Fantome! I give you Joy, I give you Joy. What do you think of your Thousand Pounds now? Why does not the Man speak?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Ha! [Taking his Hand from his Face.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis my Master! [Shrieks.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Abigal not so fast.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Are you alive, Sir? He has given my Shoulder such a cursed Tweak! they must be real Fingers. I feel 'em I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: What do'st think?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Think, Sir? Think? Troth I don't know what to think. Pray, Sir, how—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: No Questions, good Abigal. Thy Curiosity shall be satisfied in due time. Where's your Lady?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh, I'm so frighted—and so glad!—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Where's your Lady, I ask you—

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Marry I don't know where I am my self—I can't forbear weeping for Joy—

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Your Lady! I say your Lady! I must bring you to your self with one Pinch more—

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Oh! she has been talking a good while with the Steward.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Then he has open'd the whole Story to her, I'm glad he has prepar'd her. Oh! here she comes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where is he? let me fly into his Arms! my Life! my Soul! my Husband!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Oh! let me catch thee to my Heart, dearest of Women!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Are you then still alive, and are you here! I can scarce believe my Senses! Now am I happy indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: My Heart is too full to answer thee.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
How could you be so cruel to defer giving me that Joy which you knew I must receive from your Presence? You have
robb'd my Life of some Hours of Happiness that ought to have been in it.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: It was to make our Happiness the more sincere and unmixt. There will be now no Doubts to dash it. What has been the Affliction of our Lives, has given a Variety to them, and will hereafter supply us with a thousand Materials to talk of.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am now satisfy'd that it is not in the Power of Absence to lessen your Love towards me.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: And I am satisfy'd that it is not in the Power of Death to destroy that Love which makes me the happiest of Men.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Was ever Woman so blest! to find again the Darling of her Soul, when she thought him lost for ever! to enter into a kind of second Marriage with the only Man whom she was ever capable of loving!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: May it be as happy as our first, I desire no more! Believe me, my Dear, I want Words to express those Transports of Joy and Tenderness which are every Moment rising in my Heart whilst I speak to thee.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Just as the Steward told us, Lads! Look you there, if he ben't with my Lady already?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: He! he! he! what a joyful Night will this be for Madam!

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: As I was coming in at the Gate, a strange Gentleman whisk'd by me; but he took to his Heels, and made away to the George. If I did not see Master before me, I shou'd have sworn it had been his Honour!

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Ha'st given Orders for the Bells to be set a ringing?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Never trouble thy Head about that, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: [to Lady.] My Dear, I long as much to tell you my whole Story, as you do to hear it. In the mean while, I am to look upon this as my Wedding Day. I'll have nothing but the Voice of Mirth and Feasting in my House. My poor Neighbours and my Servants shall rejoyce with me. My Hall shall be free to every one, and let my Cellars be thrown open.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Ah! bless your Honour, may you never die again!

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: The same good Man that ever he was!

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Whurra!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Vellum, thou hast done me much Service to Day. I know thou lov'st Abigal, but she's disappointed in a Fortune. I'll make it up to both of you. I'll give thee a Thousand Pound with her. It is not fit there shou'd be one sad Heart in my House to Night.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What you do for Abigal, I know is meant as a Compliment to me. This is a new Instance of your Love.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Mr. Vellum, you are a well-spoken Man: Pray do you thank my Master and my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.p: Vellum, I hope you are not displeas'd with the Gift I make you.

sp.speaker: Vel.
sp.l: The Gift is Twofold. I receive from you
A virtuous Partner, and a Portion too;
For which, in humble wise, I thank the Donors:
And so we bid Good-night to both your Ho—nours.

lg.l: TO Night, the Poet's Advocate I stand,
And he deserves the Favour at my hand,
Who in my Equipage their Cause debating
Has plac'd two Lovers, and a third in waiting;
If both the first shou'd from their Duty swerve,
There's one behind the Wainscote in reserve.
In his next Play, if I wou'd take this Trouble,
He promis'd me to make the Number double:
In troth 'twas spoke like an obliging Creature,
For tho' 'tis Simple, yet it shews Good-nature.
My Help thus ask'd, I cou'd not chuse but grant it,
And really I thought the Play wou'd want it,
Void as it is of all the usual Arts
To warm your Fancies, and to steal your Hearts:
No Court-Intrigue, nor City-Cuckoldom,
No Song, no Dance, no Musick—but a Drum—
No smutty Thought in doubtful Phrase exprest;
And, Gentlemen, if so, pray where's the Jest?
When we wou'd raise your Mirth, you hardly know,
Whether in strictness you shou'd Laugh or no,
But turn upon the Ladies in the Pit,
And if they redden, you are sure 'tis Wit.
Protect him then, ye Fair ones; for the Fair
Of all Conditions are his equal Care.
He draws a Widow, who of blameless Carriage
True to her Jointure, hates a second Marriage;
